http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies that the associated page is a theme

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Themes are large-scale forces, including cable companies, historical transitions, and broad cultural formations, that have an effect on undersea cable development.

"It's either feast or famine," one cable station technician tells you. The history of the cable industry confirms this: it is littered with booms and busts. The most recent boom occurred in the late 1990s, alongside the dot com bubble. The massive amount of fiber-optic cable laid during this period now supports much of our transoceanic Internet traffic.

In the early 2000s, the cable market bust. So many systems were laid in the late 1990s that none of the cable companies obtained the amount of income that they had expected. The supply of cable capacity exceeded the demand. Companies could not recoup the hundreds of millions of dollars spent to lay these networks. 360Networks, Global Crossing, Flag, Level 3, WorldCom, and Asia Global Crossing all went into bankruptcy between 2001 and 2002. Some were later acquired for cents on the dollar. The companies then downsized drastically, often letting go of their most seasoned employees in order to save on salaries.

Although the Internet is often imagined as a “clean” and durable technology, something that will eventually be extended everywhere at little cost, this fails to register the extensive financial, social, and environmental investments required to establish cable systems. One recent report estimates that the annual cost to maintain cables ranges from $100 to $1000 per kilometer – millions of dollars per year.
When there is a telecommunications monopoly or duopoly, one or two companies carry all traffic in and out of a country. They can keep prices of capacity high and limits citizens’ access.
These are hubs of commercial activity, where cables speed up both communications and economic exchange.

Deregulation, privatization, and speculation about the growth of the Internet drove a global boom in cable laying in the late 1990s. Between 1988 and 2003, the voice paths across the Pacific increased 1.6 billion percent. Stewart Ash, who worked in cable installation at the time, recollects: “Cable manufacturers were building factories all over the place. We had a cable factory in Southampton in the U.K.. We had one in Portland, Oregon. We had another one in Australia. People were pushing out 100,000 kilometers of cable a year.”  This boom vastly expanded the undersea cable system.

In the 19th century, the first undersea network extended around the globe. The British pioneered this effort, drawing upon their technical expertise and naval resources. Many early systems followed colonial transportation and trade routes.

The Eastern Telegraph Company dominated the undersea telegraph network. It was the largest cable company in the world, and at one point operated 160,000 nautical miles of undersea cable. The company’s route linked British colonies, and its “All-Red Line” served a strategic function for the British Empire. As wireless technologies spread around the world, challenging the hegemony of cable systems, the Eastern Telegraph Company was merged with Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company – creating what would later become Cable & Wireless.

In the 1920s, a regenerator system was deployed across the undersea network. This re-boosted the telegraph signal at the cable station, effectively replacing human operators with automatic relay systems. While in the early days, a message from England to New Zealand and back might be handled thirty-eight times at nineteen stations along the way, by 1940, a message could be sent direct with no human contact.

Copper has been important to each generation of undersea cables. In telegraph and telephone cables, a conductive copper core was used to transmit signals across the network. Today's fiber-optic cables use copper to power amplifiers that lay on the seabed.

Formed in 1864, the Telegraph Construction and Maintenance Company soon became the world's largest cable manufacturer. By some reports it constructed close to 90% of the world's submarine cables over the next half-century. This map shows the vast spread of Telcon networks by 1903, from the company's hub in London, England to its peripheries in Asia, Africa, and Australia.

Obsolete cables litter the seafloor. Old cable stations slip back into the jungle. Former hubs of transnational communication lie disconnected. Trash litters the landscape. Parts of our cable network are abandoned when the cost of upkeep is just too expensive.

Global Crossing’s abandoned cable station in Ma‘ili, just south of O'ahu's two main cable landings, is marked with bullet holes. While cable stations were once central workplaces that enriched and enlivened communities, today they are more often inaccessible buildings whose benefit is often invisible to the surrounding residents. Here, residents didn’t embrace the system, but resisted it – the company encountered local dissent when they tried to lay cable beneath the town. Instead of seeing a link to a global network, locals perceived this as an intrusion of the island's colonial legacy.

While companies garner support for the newest and most advanced cables, the remnants of infrastructure failure remain. Destroyed cable stations are yet unexcavated, obsolete wireless towers remain standing, and the detritus of former networks is scattered across the Pacific.
Cable stations today are often landed in areas where property values are low. It's not surprising to find discarded objects, trash, and litter near the landing point.

Abandoned structures across the Pacific bear the traces of war. This telegraph station at Ishigaki Island was left to deteriorate after the American attack in 1945. Today it is a reminder of the trauma of past conflict. Bullet holes remain scattered across its walls and residents report that ghosts haunt the area.

Cables shape contours in the environment, leaving traces even after their circuits are disconnected. These residual effects make it more likely that new cables will be laid along existing paths, sedimenting the network in its historical geography. Cable technology also gets taken up by new industries and users over time.

Many cable buildings have been re-purposed for science. The station at Bamfield, Canada has been transformed into a Marine Sciences Research Center. Scientists seeking new species near Wellington, New Zealand briefly used the cable house at Titahi Bay. Fanning Island, on the British line, used to be a destination on the Norwegian Cruise line until the company no longer needed an international location for its Hawaiian tours. For a period of time, the University of Honolulu Oceanographic Department leased the cable facility, and the cable stations were later turned into schoolhouses.

The remnants of telegraph stations often live on solely in the historical images of cable landings and the recorded memories of cable workers. These are scattered few and far between, and often remain buried in remote archives.

In some places, obsolete cables are drawn up from the seafloor and re-laid to connect un-cabled islands. The PacRim West cable, a transpacific link, was retrieved from the ocean and used to construct a new connection to Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea: APNG-2.

The Champion West platform off the coast of Brunei is producing more oil than ever thanks to undersea cables. Shell, a company that has been active in the country since 1929, first implemented their "Smart Fields" technology here. Fiber-optic cables relay detailed information about seafloor conditions, including pressure and temperature, back to the base. With this influx of real-time data, oil workers make operational decisions more quickly, activate underground valves electronically, and increase their rate of production.

Fiber-optic cables encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass. Although in development since the early 1980s, the conservative cable industry did not lay the first transoceanic network until 1986. The immense capacity of fiber-optics have made possible the Internet as we know it today.

Many in the telecommunications industry suggest that the advent of cloud  computing – which involves storing one’s data remotely, often outside of one’s  national boundaries – is a cost-effective opportunity for developing  countries. Cloud computing would enable many islanders, even  those with low levels of domestic infrastructure, access to free Internet-based applications  such as GoogleDocs and Skype. However, the cloud would also make  them dependent on external support to finance new infrastructure.

The Southern Cross Cable Network was designed as an Internet-based cable that, at the time, would be the fastest and most straightforward route from Australia and New Zealand to the United States. Just as Southern Cross was being put in the water, the cable market collapsed – this was brought on by a combination of the excess capacity offered by the numerous cable systems laid in the late 1990s. The timing of Southern Cross was “perfect,” as its builders recollect, poised on the crest of the cable boom: if they'd started a little bit later, it likely wouldn't have happened.

During the cable boom of the late 1990s and early 2000s, a series of fiber-optic “super-stations” were built. These were often meticulously designed, completely redundant, enormous stations constructed in anticipation of future cable growth. They often had extra room for additional cable systems or “colocation” space that could house data centers, call centers, or other digital services.

Trans-Pacific Cable 5 was one of the first ring systems in the Pacific. It has two branches between Japan and the U.S.: a direct northern route and a southern crossing via Hawai'i and Guam, where it interconnects with other global networks. More than 70 telecom companies from over 40 countries were involved in its construction, and two-thirds of its capacity was reserved before it entered service in the mid-1990s. TPC-5’s southern line carried high-definition television broadcasts for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta.

In the 1990s, new private cable networks competed with older consortium-run systems that had long run the undersea network. While consortium systems often had upfront financing, private networks had to convince banks to lend them hundreds of millions of dollars. The FLAG system, famously written about by Neal Stephenson in his article "Mother Earth, Mother Board," was once such network. It linked up thirteen countries with more than 17,000 miles of cable.

At the opposite end of the spectrum from the fiber-optic super-station is a modern version of the “cable hut,” smaller in scale and built just big enough for the capacity running through it. One engineer describes these as “functional equipment buildings,” and from the outside they often look like windowless office buildings, blending into an industrial landscape.

The Japan-U.S. cable network was one of several ring networks laid at the turn of the twenty-first century. It cost over a billion dollars and has connected three landing sites in Japan with two U.S. stations via a direct northern route and a southern route through Hawai'i. Owned by a 35-member consortium, the cable has been upgraded to transmit more than 15 times its original capacity.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1990-2003 (AtlanticCable.com says landed at Cape D' Aguilar; Subsea Book says Deep Water Bay)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This 735km cable has connected Hong Kong and Taiwan since 1990. However, its low capacity of 420 MB/s and the bursting of the telecommunications bubble in 2001 meant that it was decommissioned long before it was technically obsolete.

Entering service in March 1999, this optical cable connects the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company’s station in Batangas with AT&T’s landing point in Guam, where connections are made to several Asia-U.S. networks. It was designed to complement and ease congestion along existing Asian and trans-Pacific cable systems.

In 2010, the Honotua cable – stretching between Hawai‘i and Tahiti – was made possible by funding from the French Government, granted as part of a wider measure to extend broadband to French citizens and improve the country’s digital economy.

The JASURAUS cable was an innovative route, planned to connect Port Hedland on Australia's northwest coast with Indonesia in 1997. Yet after the difficulties in laying the system, subsequent cables were directed south to Perth. As JASURAUS's capacity was overwhelmed by the demands of modern Internet usage in the years to follow, it became a mere backup system for Australian traffic.

One of the first fiber cable systems laid in the Pacific, Hawaii-4 was also one of the shortest lived. It went out of service after a mere 15 years, not because it broke, but rather due to economic obsolescence.

Before the fiber-optic cable PTAT was laid, the undersea cable industry was literally and figuratively a very "clubby" world, remarks telecommunications lawyer Andrew Lipman. PTAT's lawyers broke the consortium mold. Inspired by PanAmSat, which had upset the monopoly in satellite communications only years before, the entrepreneurs behind PTAT thought, "if there could be a private international satellite why couldn’t there be a private international cable?" They raised money independent of the communications monopolies and got approvals from the United States and United Kingdom governments, riding on the crest of the then emerging move toward competition. "We were able to first show that it was feasible," Lipman observes. Seeing the possibilities, a whole wave of private systems followed.
Hawaii-5 was AT&T's second fiber-optic cable between California and Hawai'i, yet like their first fiber-optic link, the line was economically obsolete in only twelve years.

The CKC (China-Korea Cable), completed in 1996 and since decommissioned, was the first underwater optical telephone cable to connect China and Korea. Its opening was commemorated by a Chinese postage stamp featuring a blue and green map of the two landing sites at Qingdao and Taean. The sites are marked by silhouettes of traditional buildings and are joined by a thin red line. A brightly colored cable, complete with pulsing light waves and a metallic signal repeater, runs across the bottom of the stamp.
Submerged under miles of water for decades, cables are one of the least visible of all infrastructures. They are also deliberately hidden.

Many telegraph cable stations remain unexcavated, unknown, and insignificant to our historical landscape. The ruins at Guam are the only landing site even commemorated along the original Commercial Pacific Cable route and, as they are located on the military base, are not accessible to the public. The ruins at Midway Island cannot be accessed since there are no regular commercial flights to the atoll. Only military, research teams, and eco-expeditions that charter flights may visit. Here, telegraph histories have been erased from memory.

Some urban cable stations attempt to “blend in” with the cityscape in order to avoid interference. Instead of fences and cameras, they hide in plain view, appearing like any other building. While surveillance technologies focus on making the surrounding area visible to the station, this tactic focuses on making the station invisible to the public.

Information about cables has often been withheld in a strategy of “security through obscurity.” The reasoning goes: if the public doesn’t know about the importance of undersea cables, they will not think to disrupt them. Many cable stations attempt to blend into the environment and deter attention from the building’s function. One cable builder says that they want to “make the building as non-descript as possible.”

The invisibility of undersea cables allowed companies to extend networks to places where they might have otherwise been opposed. When there was resistance to the installation of the telegraph in China because it conflicted with customary beliefs (the Chinese government rejected plans to link land telegraph lines to treaty ports), undersea cables were secretly brought ashore in the middle of the night.

In the 1950s, analogue coaxial cables extended across the oceans. These new systems revolutionized cable laying: they were not only able to carry telephone conversations, but telegraph messages, telex transmissions, photo-telegrams, and even slow scan television.

Cables were necessary even in the space race. The COMPAC and SEACOM coaxial cables helped to launch the first American into outer space. Because of the need for “secure” circuits, the primary route between space control centers in the United States and Australia extended via a cable from California to Sydney via Auckland and a back-up circuit was established via cables through Guam.

Although many tasks in the undersea telephone network were automated, human labor remained important to its operation. A staff of technicians performed routine maintenance on the system, including testing circuits, coordinating network traffic, and monitoring the terminal equipment. The stations were often manned twenty four hours a day and seven days a week.

In the coaxial era, the social landscape of cable stations changed dramatically. As former colonies gained independence, the network’s stations were reconfigured as gateways to new nations. Yet, currents extending through the cable station could be perceived as a continuing intrusion of foreign power. In the 1960s, anti-British rioting in Indonesia cut communications to Malaysia and forced staff members to move to Singapore.

The Tumon Bay cable station was built for a cutting edge transpacific telephone network in the 1960s. At its commemoration, Guam’s governor stated: “The station is a most welcome addition to our island, both functional and beautiful in its thin-shell, barrel vault roof design—the first of its kind on Guam… this roof contains exactly the same amount of concrete as a flat roof, yet is vastly more pleasing to the eye.” It was designed by a local architect, utilized local labor and materials, and was applauded for its connections to its environment.

Colonial powers paved the way for global telegraph networks. The All-Red Line extended around the world, linking British territories and helping to protect the empire. Other lines supported the expansion of Japanese, French, American, German, and Dutch interests across the region.

Colonial cable stations, referred to as "cable colonies" or "frontier stations," were often large buildings and centers of community in remote or foreign lands. These stations were self-sufficient and insular spaces where cable companies reproduced a microcosm of empire.

From the beginning, the Dutch colonization of Indonesia was a commercial campaign. The Dutch East Indies Company monopolized the islands' spice trade and later set up plantations. In the latter half of the nineteenth century, cables were strung between their key ports, facilitating both trade and governance. By 1904, the Dutch East Indies Government's network spanned thousands of nautical miles.

The first global telegraph network followed the pathways of British Empire, linking together its major ports and remote outposts. In many cases, however, the effectiveness of undersea cables in actually securing colonies was an aspiration rather than a reality. Local leaders “distorted the facts to suit their own ambitions,” and in some places, the telegraph helped to charge a budding nationalism.

The infrastructures of colonial empires could not have been built without the labor of slaves and indentured servants. Across the Pacific and Indian Oceans, people were removed from their homes and put to work on cities, railways, and cable systems. The expenses saved through this practice made transoceanic networks both possible and profitable.
The cable network can be divided into several different zones, including its central gateways, constricted route lines, and coastal landing points.

The link between two locations in a network is termed an “edge” in network theory. An edge is often drawn as a simple line between two nodes, a vector independent of time and place. We rarely see beyond its horizon, into the spaces where connections are formed.

The narrow points where cables run together are pressure points, sites where currents can be diverted or re-routed using minimal force. Here, local actors often have a disproportionate amount of power.

Like seaports and airports, cable stations are gateways, places that function as a region’s entry and exit point. Here, different forms of traffic are interconnected: transportation routes are leveraged to support labor, biopower is channeled to transfer information, and electrical grids are harnessed to transmit signals under the ocean.

Moving out from the cable station, where signals are monitored, powered, and processed, towards the deep sea, undersea cables must first traverse roads, beaches, and coastal waters inhabited by aquatic creatures and terrestrial publics. This zone is the cable landing point, described in the industry as a “transition environment.” While the cable station has been conceptualized as a potential target throughout its history, the cable landing point has rarely been seen as an area needing protection.

Instead of defending from a possible attack from above, today’s cable stations protect communication from potential terrorist attacks on the ground. This entails creating a “buffer zone” around the station in order to make it difficult to see and access from the outside. Immediately after 9-11, the military surrounded several cable stations on United States soil because they were considered possible targets. The number of cameras monitoring the stations increased. In some places, trees around the station have been cleared out and proximate infrastructures relocated. Cable stations want to see all but be seen by none.
Cable companies attempt to make the ocean a stable place for Internet development, but this clashes with fishermen’s need for mobility on the seas.

In some places, engineers report that fishermen deliberately fish around the cable in the hopes of being paid to stay away. These payoffs are one form of keeping them invested in the cable’s operation. A cable manager recounts that they initially had “fishermen problems” around SEA-WE-ME-3, but after buying a few licenses from them, the problem was solved: “So they got money, so we got rid of a point of aggravation. At the end of the day, we became sensitive to their concerns.”

Fishermen have caused more disruptions to cable systems than any design flaws, acts of nature, or hostile armies. After five years of work, the first undersea cable across the English Channel was completed – and then abruptly severed by a fisherman. Rumor has it that the fisherman who caught the cable later exhibited it as a rare seaweed with a gold center. Over the years, cable companies have struggled with fishermen, and the governments that regulate them, to develop forms of protection: no-fishing zones, no-anchorage zones, notices to mariners, penalties, and cable charts.

Most disruptions of cable networks are accidental, but cable engineers suspect that some are deliberate. One recalls a rumor that before their cables came into Morro Bay, there had been a nearby refinery with a pipeline extending out to sea. In order to keep the fishermen off the line, the refinery had compensated local fishermen to stay away from the pipe. The engineer suspected that when the refinery closed, the fishermen thought “Ah! We need to find another source of income! Submarine cables!”

Historically, governments have valued fish over cables. In 1908, the British Parliament refused to limit fishing near cables, commenting that fishing “represents a capital of several millions, gives employment to a body of hardy and industrious men, and supplies a substantial part of the food of the people.” Cable companies were out of luck. After an Auckland-Suva cable was damaged in 1949, the New Zealand Marine Department suggested that the fault was in part the cable company's. They argued that if cables were just laid with enough slack they would fall “flat on the sea bed and so present little hazard to trawls.” Cable companies even tried to appeal to fishermen directly, meeting with fishing vessel owners’ associations and attending their exhibitions. Going to the fishing industry, they argued: “the world must have cables, for without cables you cannot sell your fish.”

The sea here is divided. In order to protect undersea cables (and the signals running along them) from fishermen's anchors and nets, cables have often been limited to a narrow protection zone. Almost all of Australia’s cables are laid through two such zones in Sydney. While this helps to protect cable traffic from anchors and nets, it can also be limiting - ultimately Australia’s network is vulnerable for lack of redundancy. More zones would make our networks stronger, but each one has to be negotiated with fishermen.
Trawling – a form of fishing that involves dragging nets along the seafloor – sometimes includes cables in its catch, severing the network as it pulls them up.

We often think about the Internet as an urban matter, a system linking cities around the world. And when we look at the ocean, we often see a natural and wild space. Our undersea network’s routes and pressure points, however, have often been shaped by aquatic and coastal environments.

The deep and dynamic ocean – with its currents, waves, gyres, and eddies – is the safest part of a cable route. Very few breaks occur in the deep ocean, where cables function for decades without interruption. Here they are safe from national interception, fishing traffic, and ships' anchors.

The ocean serves as a medium for signal traffic. For current to move through any electrical system, the circuit needs to be “grounded,” that is, wired to a point with lower electrical energy. In the case of undersea cables, a signal moves through the cable across the ocean, and then the circuit completes via an “ocean ground bed,” which redirects electrical current back through the ocean. One cable report observes that powering a system “is achieved by actually using the environment – the seawater – as a conductor to complete the circuit.” In contrast to a view of the ocean as unwieldy and unstable, cable infrastructure harnesses the watery environment to transmit signals.

For many, ocean waters might seem like a threat to undersea transmissions, a material that would intercept the electric signal and break the circuit. In reality, this threat is minimal. In some places, however, the rising sea and intensified storms pose an increasing risk to coastal cable stations.
There is an entire marine maintenance industry that has to be funded by cable owners even in the absence of any breaks.

We often imagine the Internet as something above us, bouncing through the air, in a “cloud.” Cell phone towers and satellites direct our attention above rather than below. Yet these wireless forms have almost always been connected to grounded infrastructures.

Although wired and wireless technologies are often seen as competitors, in reality, cables and satellites have different geographies, markets, and technological strengths. Satellites, with their wide field of reception, have been more useful for rural areas, islands, and the transmission of television. Over the last twenty years, however, satellite capacity has filled up and traffic has shifted to cables. They are able to carry a greater amount of information at faster speeds and at lower cost. Many visible satellite dishes, mounted on rooftops and near telecom buildings, are relics of the past.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: An earlier time in Fiji's history...

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The satellite at the Vatuwaqa cable station in Fiji is a reminder of an earlier time in Fiji’s history, when the country had invested heavily in wireless communications. With the emergence of fiber-optic cables, Fiji found itself struggling to maintain its position as a hub in the South Pacific. In the late 1990s, Fiji decided to connect to the Southern Cross Cable Network, which involved generating an enormous amount of capital, $48.5 million, on its own. The debt acquired from the cable and the costs of maintenance led to a push in the early 2000s to develop media-heavy industries as a new source for signal flow.

Setting up a wireless telegraph network required much less investment than expensive, labor-intensive undersea systems. These new technologies made it possible for locations once marginalized by the cable system to become a part of transoceanic signal networks. They also introduced a new form of military communications, and thus a new form of warfare.

When radio communication was developed, it did not replace undersea cables. As one reporter observed in the 1920s: “The truth of the matter is that wireless and cable communications supplement one another." He adds, "but the use of the cable... has one outstanding advantage over wireless – secrecy.” Although in the coming decades, signals broadcast via radio waves would be scanned and intercepted, cables were not immune to foreign monitoring.
Although cables often remain in the periphery of our vision, the presence of huge radio towers can signify cables beneath. Wireless and wired geographies often overlay one another.

On the horizon, huge white domes dot the landscape. These are "radomes," a protective covering that keeps sensitive tracking equipment safe from the weather and from would-be observers. At both of these locations, in the center of the Pacific and at its northern edge, radar has been critical to United States defense.
The circulation of signals through our undersea networks depends on the circulation of bodies across the diverse environments of the Pacific Rim.

Nested in the wilderness, many cable stations became centers of social activity. In Fiji, tennis, rugby, and picnicking were popular pastimes, and several of the men owned boats which they took out for weekend parties. Visiting other parts of the islands, they brought the chiefs the “customary bottle of whisky” in order to enjoy fishing in their lands.  On Fanning Island, the cablemen held canoe races and formed a Gun Club where they shot clay pigeons. Bamfield had very little indoor entertainment until the cable station arrived, subsequent to which the following were established: a Saturday night movie open to the public, a dance hall with a five-piece cableman orchestra, and annual dances at the end of the summer and New Year’s (to which local residents would travel for hours to attend). “It was like living in a country club,” one cableman recounted.

The training of cable operators conditions both the body and the mind. The first telegraph signals on undersea cables had to be written out in full and retransmitted, and early operators had to cultivate both the correct wrist action and a steady focus to endure long hours of writing. Then, as is still true today, much of the knowledge of cable operation is passed down informally from generation to generation via on-the-job training.

In the telegraph era, cable companies maintained a distinct social composition by tightly controlling the national affiliation of the cablemen. Stations operated by British companies were initially staffed only with British workers. Local men weren't usually trained as operators, despite the fact that the men from abroad were not necessarily more qualified. On-site accommodation also kept cablemen from finding homes in nearby towns. These policies made sure that workers would maintain their connection to a distant homeland and prevented information, expertise, and resources from diffusing to those outside of the cable colony.
Even though today's networks are often hidden from us, over history cable systems have been made visible to select publics.

The cable's beach landing, especially in the telegraph era, involved many men who helped to pull the cable ashore and was an event watched by many local residents. In the later telephone and fiber-optic periods, it became less and less of a spectacle, though images of cable landings are sometimes still posted on communications companies' websites.

At some landing points, monuments celebrate cable history. At Southport’s "cable park," a monument commemorates the Pacific Cable Board telegraph system. A large map, engraved in metal, shows the colonial routes across the Pacific. A quote from Shakespeare, “I’ll put a girdle round about the earth in forty minutes,” anchors the system in British history. In Northland, New Zealand and Darwin, Australia, stones mark the spot of the original cable route. Few of these monuments are located near existing cable landing points.

Arriving here, you find the cable marked on a nautical chart. These squiggly route lines have long been drawn as an attempt to keep fishermen and other boaters off the cable route. If fishermen don't know where the cable lies, they might accidentally drop an anchor on it, severing the connection.

Cable stations were the vibrant and visible nodes of early telegraph networks. Far from the secrecy that surrounds the station today, cable stations and landing sites were drawn on commemorative cable envelopes, postcards, and postage stamps, and at times their addresses were even indicated on the delivered cablegram.

To “sell” the COMPAC cable to users who might be skeptical of long-distance calls, the cable’s management committee cultivated news coverage about it in print, radio, and television, contacted journalists and camera crews to document the landings, arranged speeches about the system, and encouraged schools to “adopt” and follow Cable and Wireless cableships. To culminate the laying, they staged elaborate opening ceremonies with souvenir programs. Some were even covered by live television.
Even as far back as the nineteenth century, cables have been used to speed up the development of economies around the world.

Many cables were linked to Chinese treaty ports in the 1800s and early 1900s. These were intended to help "open up" the Chinese economy to trade with Western nations. Today, cables continue to interconnect developing regions with the global economy.

Cables have long facilitated economic development and the extraction of natural resources. An 1894 article about the cable to Labuan island notes that it will assist in the development of the British Mines there, then being worked by the New Central Borneo Company, Ltd.. A railway was to be connected between the mines and the shipping port, and in turn to the cable landing. The author writes, "Doubtless one effect of the cable will be to stimulate every branch of industry, and to beneficially affect both the export and import trade, not only in that Colony, but in the adjourning territories.”

Cables are important, and some say even an essential resource, to islands and remote areas with developing economies. They can increase reliability for weather reporting, including tsunami warning systems, and support higher bandwidth applications for less money, assisting in development. Reflecting on the recent installation of the HANTRU-1 cable, the President of the Marshall Islands Telecommunications Authority claimed: “Connecting to the global fiber optic network promises to be nothing short of transformational for an isolated country such as the Marshall Islands.”

There are more proposals to draw remote locations into the global network than ever before, yet undersea cables will never be able to connect all of the world's islands. There will always be populations that are too expensive enough to reach. Despite the expanses of the cable system, there remains a multi-tiered communication system and a digital divide.

Around the year 2000, Alan Seid began to think about undersea cables. On a visit to Palau, Bill Crawley, who helped to lay the globe-spanning FLAG network, told him: “you’ll need cables to bring Palau to a new level of communications.” But this seemed a dream beyond the reach of Alan’s company, Palau Telecoms. They would need $55 million dollars, far more than their small country could afford.

Cables not only route electrical power under the ocean, but political power across its surface. Some nations use cables to monitor communications and to expand their control over remote territories. Others are forced to rely on foreign-owned systems for their economic stability.

Cables increase the susceptibility of media to surveillance and censorship. British control of telegraph networks in the 1900s gave the country the ability to intercept and censor messages, especially during wartime. The United States' dominance of telegraph networks in the Philippines helped them to develop as a surveillance state. Cable surveillance capacities are still being leveraged today. The British Government Communications Headquarters and the National Security Agency are both known to collect information as it passes through fiber-optic links.

In technical terms, a short circuit or a “shunt fault” is a type of disconnection where the insulation is severed, but the conductor remains partially intact. This enables power to flow out into its proximate environment, and in some cases operations can continue. Short-circuiting is an intervention that does not completely sever a connection but instead breaks its layers of protection, feeding power to those around it.

Remote and developing areas often depend on external assistance to set up cable systems, especially in tropical environments. Given their lack of insulation and relatively small amount of traffic, cables at the fringes of the network are more vulnerable, and operators must do more to interconnect with existing networks.

To military strategists, telegraph cables were the most efficient and secure mode of communication with colonial territories, especially during wartime. Even when they did not actually increase control over linked lands, these systems represent a belief that undersea cables could secure economic and political investment.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: The social life of undersea cables

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Cable networks are not merely technical infrastructures, but encompass social worlds. They are places of community, collaboration, and tourism.

Some early telegraph stations became tourist destinations open to the public. During summers, “droves of tourists” would arrive at the Bamfield cable station. A summer cruise to the Northland of New Zealand made the Doubtless Bay station a stop, and the superintendent greeted tourists on their trip. Given the repetitious nature of the job, station operators welcomed the visitors. Today, tours of stations are occasionally given to commemorate the opening of new systems.

Since the beginning of cable work, cablemen have mediated station happenings in telegraph journals and magazines. The Eastern Telegraph Company’s monthly “family magazine,” The Zodiac, was widely circulated around the globe. Here cablemen separated by oceans shared their experiences on the frontier.

The social connections of the cable industry are tight. The Chairman of Cable & Wireless once wrote: “The company is, in fact, a huge continuing international family.”  Another cableman reflected that the cable system “was like an extended family. Wherever you went in the world, if you visited a cable station, you were bound to meet someone you knew or had heard about.” Technicians, operators, engineers, and managers respect each other’s work and view the operation of global cable networks as a collaborative activity.

Underlying the technical infrastructure of undersea networks is a tight-knit cable community. Many cable workers have been in the industry for decades, and almost everyone knows everyone. These men and women often have a shared sense of purpose in creating the communications system that links their nations to the world.

After they come aground, undersea cables terminate at a cable landing station. Here, transmitted signals, including dots and dashes, voices, and data are routed between systems. Stations are also social centers where cablemen come together to maintain the network.

In the colonial era, the cable station's walls were porous – cable companies accommodated tourists and encouraged public participation in station events. But in the Cold War era, those who were not “part” of the network were rarely allowed inside. Companies regulated access in order to protect their circuit. Visitors were typically permitted entrance only when accompanied by officers who had been cleared. One author remarks, “Growing up in Heart’s Content in the 1950s, unless your father worked at the cable station you probably never got to see inside the door.”

These locations are critical nodes, where power is embedded in more than just cable routes. At these sites, companies can draw from layers of support infrastructure, route outward transmissions along a number of paths, and more easily generate economic surpluses.
As cables wind along the earth's surface, secluded in the depths of the ocean, they become entangled in other aquatic processes, from oil extraction to the growth of marine life.

Undersea cables have been used for offshore development since the coaxial era, but as oil and gas platforms are extended further and further out to the sea, they are more dependent on effective communications, especially the secure lines of cable systems. Cables have been deployed to platforms around the world, in Brunei, Brazil, Thailand, and Australia. Cables not only link platforms to land, but to instruments on the bottom of the seafloor.

Laying reliable cables requires immense knowledge about the ocean’s depth and composition. If cables are draped across valleys, they risk being caught in currents. If they are routed diagonally down steep slopes, they might be broken by landslides. If laid across sunken ships or coral reefs, they could become twisted and tangled.

In the 1940s and 1950s, oceanic space was surveilled and militarized. Navies developed secret networks of undersea cables that could listen for enemy submarines. In the United States, the Navy joined forces with AT&T to implement the Sound Surveillance System, which used hydrophones to monitor the ocean for Soviet presence.

In Rudyard Kipling’s poem, “The Deep-Sea Cables,” he describes the telegraph cables’ seafloor environment: “The wrecks dissolve above us; their dust drops down from afar; Down to the dark, to the utter dark, where the blind white sea-snakes are; There is no sound, no echo of sound, in the deserts of the deep; Or the great gray level plains of ooze where the shell-burred cables creep.” Here, the earth and the depths of the ocean seem far apart, even though human communication depended on movement through the deep sea.

Security has always been critical to network development. Companies plan and route systems in ways that to protect them from potential interference, ranging from international surveillance to the turbulence of the natural environment.

While in the coaxial era, stations were constructed like bunkers in order to protect against potential nuclear threats, today, security has to do with barriers and visibility at the station's perimeter. One cable station manager says that their facility is secure because it is located in a fairly isolated area, with high fences, barbed wire, and an automatic gate with video cameras operated by staff who will only open it if they recognize the guest. There are about 60 actively monitored video cameras and the police regularly visit to make sure that there is nothing out of order. At night, barriers block off the roadway, giving them multiple layers of protection.

Nodes in our cable network require a stable political environment. One cable builder recounts his conversation with a government official. He said, “Your army could take it over,” and they said, “Well, we don’t have an army.” “I see,” he replied, "Okay, your police.” “Police?” they asked. He said, “Okay, who in this country has got guns? Someone’s got guns. Someone with guns could take it over.” They conceded, “Yeah, you’re right.  Someone could.””

Cables are considered “critical infrastructure” by many countries, a term that means they are critical to a nation’s economic, financial, and social stability. In a number of places, security measures have been increased to control cable operations. In the United States, a group of actors and agencies known as “Team Telecom” review applications and clear cable projects  – this group has made it increasingly difficult to land on American soil.

Cable systems are vulnerable both to external hazards and threats from within: an immense amount of time, energy, and manual labor are required to sustain undersea networks, and without it, the infrastructure would soon fail.
The geography of cable routes reflects a number of concerns, ranging from an interest in keeping lines separate for protection to a need for the shortest path between nodes.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies a path that should operate as a ring, with the last page connecting back to the first page

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: To ensure redundancy, some cable systems are laid in a ring, with two given paths between any two points. This is an expensive approach to network design, but if one segment breaks, traffic can automatically be re-routed in opposite direction. During the cable boom of the 1990s, many ring systems were built, providing diverse routes to stations such as Miyazaki and Ninomiya in Japan.

Cables are sometimes laid to locations that already have enough capacity. This is often done in order to generate diversity – multiple, disparate pathways to a node – which makes traffic overall more reliable. Australia used to be one of the most diversely connected countries, with at least six zones where telegraphs landed. Over the years this has decreased: most traffic now runs through Sydney. Recent proponents for landing a cable in Perth have argued that the country needs to diversify its routes once again.

Urban hubs have been variously seen as a source of danger, since they bring potential disruptions, and as a source of protection. After World War I, some cable stations were relocated closer to major cities, which would offer protection. Following World War II, many systems were removed from urban centers to keep them from threatening populations and nuclear bombs.

The shortest cable route, the one with the least "latency," has gained a new importance with the development of the Internet. Microseconds make a difference to high-frequency traders who use computer programs to take advantage of slight changes in price in different locations. Companies with a more direct connection can exploit this for profit. It has been estimated that merely a few milliseconds can result in a $20 million dollar difference in the span of a month.
Signal traffic rarely moves in a straight line between origin and destination. More often our signals move in a circuitous route, determined by economic and geopolitical factors.
The techniques that humans use to operate a cable system, whether the backing up of equipment or the splicing together of networks, have always been shaped by the cultural practices of their time.

The final moment at which cables are joined is the splice. This can happen at cable landings or on boats in the middle of the ocean. Whether the cablemen are splicing together the copper core of a telephone cable or the strands of glass at the center of a fiber-optic cable, this is a moment that takes skill. The engineer in charge tells visitors that they are allowed to take pictures of everything except for the actual splice. This has to remain secret.

In order to ensure that the signal never drops, cable stations back up all critical equipment. As one technician explains: the “whole building is N+1” with a completely redundant system ready to take over if the first fails. Power is supplied from both ends of the cable: either end can sustain the system if the other goes out. Spares of critical equipment are kept in case of an emergency. In some stations, every cabinet in the room can be reached by two diverse routes. If any wire is accidentally cut, nobody loses service.
To protect their cables, companies often bury systems under the ground and the sea.

The cable’s beach landing has been the single most commemorated event in undersea cable history. Traces can be found in scrapbooks, home movie footage, cable companies’ websites, and historical texts. To document or be present at a cable landing is to be a witness to the coming together of nations or worlds.
The creation of a cable system requires a new set of architectures: cable huts on the beach, cable stations where signals terminate and, in the telegraph era, housing for cable workers.

Colonial cable houses were massive and resilient structures that sheltered cablemen from the threats of the frontier. After large telegraph crews were no longer needed, some of these were renovated and repurposed. The original cable station in Fiji now houses FINTEL, the country's international telecommunications carrier. After the cable station in Darwin, Australia was bombed during World War II, the original cable manager's house was turned into a museum.

While American cable stations often blend into the environment, in other places stations are surrounded by twelve foot walls. Cable infrastructure looks slightly different everywhere you go, and its forms of protection reflect the threats of each particular environment. In the Philippines, walls keep people on the ground out of the station. Approaching it from the street, you can't even see inside.

After World War II, undersea cables had to be secured from nuclear bombs. Many cable stations were located underground in fallout shelters. Installations on U.S. territory, including those at Guam and Hawai'i, had to be built according to military specifications and had walls between 18 and 24 inches thick. There were showers where employees could wash off radioactive material and kitchens stocked with food in the case of an attack. These forms of protection were termed “hardening.”

When telegraph cables came ashore, they first connected to a small building on the beach, the "cable hut." This tiny structure protected the connection between the submarine cable and the attached land line.
Cable companies have devised strategies to protect their networks, ranging from warning signs to monitoring the cable route with geographic information systems.

When tracking cables, look for bright colors, posts labeled "Do Not Dig," and other warning signs. These are almost always the remnants of local negotiations over cable routes. If you can read them correctly, you will find your way into the cable's history.

The relative centralization of cable systems them less resilient than we might imagine. In 2006 an earthquake near Taiwan set off an undersea landslide and snapped several cables. Another significant outage happened in Vietnam in 2007 when cable thieves pulled up two of the country’s working lines, forcing 82% of traffic onto one cable. While network carriers are often able to re-route signals, in many cases breaks decrease Internet connectivity.
Mounted on posts high up in the air, these signs are meant for boaters that cross the coastal waters. Like the nautical charts that publicly reveal cable routes, "Do Not Anchor" is their message.

In Hawai‘i, the politics of one road have made it difficult to land international systems. Farrington Highway is a central route for those on the island’s west shore: for the military, for industries, and for local communities. In 1999, when AT&T dug up the road to reconnect its stations, the disruption in the daily lives of local communities caused an outcry and the cable station manager reports that some of the residents came to think of AT&T as the “enemy.” He reflects that he spends much of his time addressing the claims of residents in the towns along Farrington Highway, a route he describes as “one way in and one way out.”
Even though we think of our information networks as less and less material, laying cable still depends on manual labor at a number of critical points.

In the telegraph era, the cableman was a key gateway to the system. His smallest movements could have large-scale effects. One cableman recollects: “during our solitary watches of six hours, we were … the only links completing communication between Home and the Colonies ... Until relieved at the end of a duty, intercourse between Australia and the rest of the world depended entirely upon the man at the circuit.” Today, the work of cablemen is still important to the maintenance of signal traffic. They no longer have to perceive and re-transmit messages, but they must regularly visit the cable station to check up on the equipment and ensure that everything is in order. Network engineers monitor traffic and repair broken lines. Without their work, our global communications networks would fall apart.

Being an undersea telegrapher was an exacting job. The global network spanned time zones and cablemen often had to work overnight to receive traffic during business hours in another part of the world. In the early days of telegraphy, operators sensed signals by watching a light move back and forth across a small strip, a practice that strained their eyes, and then retransmitted the signal on a connecting circuit, which strained their wrists. To make the signal visible, the men were enclosed in dark rooms with much of the light and air blocked out.

Network repair can be difficult, only in part due to the hassle of retrieving cables from miles below the ocean's surface. In some places, including China, Italy, and Indonesia, companies have to wait for permits before they can fix their systems. Cable repair is also dependent on a small number of specialized cable ships.

Cable routes, especially in tropical locations, have to regularly cleared, mowed, and patrolled. Sometimes systems have to be dug up to make way for new lines. Maintenance is a resource-intensive process that consumes a significant part of the station's operating budget. Without it, network infrastructure would soon be overgrown.

In the fiber-optic era, the undersea network was “opened up.” Government-owned and affiliated telecommunications companies were broken up and sold off to private investors, creating opportunities for new players to enter the industry. Many cable projects became speculative money making ventures rather than “supporters of national industry and public service.”

Following deregulation, private cable systems introduced a new geography of landing points, since existing companies often blocked private networks from terminating at their stations. While many historical monopolies resisted the change, in the end, the new nodes were interconnected with the old ones, and the boom helped to create duplicate routes across the oceans and ultimately, a more secure network.

In the 1990s, telecommunications companies downsized. Alcatel reduced 48% of their workforce in undersea networks. AT&T cut 123,000 jobs between 1991 and 1995, 30% of its labor force. Much of the labor has been now been outsourced to network operations centers or delegated to computers.
The last two decades have seen the rapid spread of the “technology park.” These areas house a range of technology companies, often offering tax breaks and other incentives to lure development.

The expansion of the undersea network depends on advances in marine science, from the mapping of the ocean's depths to the creation of new subsea exploration technology. In turn, cables have also helped to generate new scientific knowledge.

Where transoceanic cables once extended, there are now large seafloor observatories, undersea networks that connect scientific instruments on the bottom of the ocean. In the Pacific Northwest, the NEPTUNE network and the Regional Scale Nodes project enable scientists to communicate with the ocean itself and track seafloor processes as they occur in real time. These build on investments in earlier systems. NEPTUNE's researchers conduct maintenance from the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Up the inlet at Port Alberni, this cable terminates in a station built for a 1960s coaxial system. Much further south, in Oregon, the Regional Scale Nodes network also connects to a former transpacific cable station.

The seafloor survey is a critical part of laying submarine cable. Early telegraph surveys were conducted by throwing a weighted line overboard, imperfectly gauging the route and draping the cable over valleys. Today’s cable surveyors have computers that can continually index the ocean beneath them, and as a result, can lay the cable precisely along subsea ridges. Seafloor data is valuable and isn’t typically shared with other companies.

In the nineteenth century, navigation was a formidable challenge. Charts were inaccurate and shipwrecks occurred regularly. Large numbers of lives were lost and marine commerce was unreliable. For better charts, marine scientists needed to determine longitude exactly – this depended on the ability to make astronomical observations in different locations at precisely the same time. Before undersea cables, time was not standardized around the world. But after continents were linked, mapmakers could compare the times at two cable stations and thus determine their longitude. When the first transpacific cable was laid, equipment was set up to use them for longitude experiments. By 1903, “longitude from the west clasped hands with longitude from the east, and the first astronomic girdle of the world was completed.”
To run smoothly, cable systems must be interconnected with transportation systems, including airports, roads, and ports.

Ports are both a benefit and threat to cables. While many early links overlaid shipping lines, cable layers found that ships’ anchors were their most frequent form of disruption. Care was taken to dislocate many cables from ports, despite the need to interconnect traffic between them. Some cables are still laid to centers of shipping, such as Singapore, causing constant anxiety about potential disruption.

The friction-free operation of the cable station directly depends on its interconnection with other friction-free local infrastructures, especially the road. When roads are blocked, maintenance can be delayed and networks made inaccessible.

Before the telegraph, trains were an important mode of long distance communication. Like many other new media forms, telegraphs both layered onto and extended existing networks. They were used to enhance the reliability of trains and were often centered in hubs of railway transit.

Cables are absolutely crucial for air travel today. If our information networks went down, airlines would not be able to process credit cards and air traffic controllers around the world could not coordinate their activities. Yet this is a two-way exchange. To build and maintain cables, workers in the industry also rely on air transportation.
A cable network is an assemblage of many technologies, including the cables themselves, the ships that lay them, and the submerged repeaters that boost signals on the ocean floor.

Cable stations rely on a number of sources to power the movement of data: battery plants, local electrical grids, and backup power generators. The power bill for a single station can be tens of thousands of US dollars a month.

The cable's installation has all but disappeared from sight. While early systems required teams of men to dig long trenches, today's cables often snake underground and out of view. The modern technique of horizontal drilling uses machines to extend the conduit beneath land and sea.
Terrestrial wires can remain without an insulating layer because air keeps signals from diffusing. Without insulation, signals on undersea cables would dissipate into a conductive ocean.

Cable ships are enormous boats that can carry hundreds of miles of submarine cable below their decks. On today’s ships expansive control systems and seafloor measurement technologies ensure that the cable will land precisely along a projected route.

The culture of the Cold War affected the development of coaxial systems in the 1950s. Cable stations were fortified, closed off, and decentralized from urban hubs, where they would be safe from the threat of nuclear attack.

During the Cold War, there was a move toward infrastructural decentralization. These stations were tucked away in suburban or rural areas, seemingly more secure from the threat of anchors and potential nuclear attack. This strategy also protected cables from the rising costs of urban coastal property, as well as swelling populations that could inadvertently disrupt cable systems.

Cables are resources and they depend on resources. Systems require electrical networks, transportation grids, and shipping lines. They’ve been used to transmit information about farming, mining, and global trade.

Infrastructures are layered over infrastructures. Cables require an electrical grid. Stations have backup generators and battery plants inside to ensure that even if this grid fails, the station will never go offline. In many places, cable stations are located near large power plants.

The Gulf of Thailand (GoT) Fiber Link Project is just one of many undersea systems that bridge offshore platforms, allowing the oil and gas industry to monitor, process, and analyze data about extraction. In this image, leaders of Thailand and CAT Telecom celebrate the project's launch in Bangkok, not far from Sri Racha. The Chevron Thailand president announced, “Technology and innovation are critical to increasing our our ability to conduct safe, reliable, and efficient operations...a rapid and reliable IT system is critical for operational performance.”
The environments that cables run through are not friction-free landscapes, but turbulent ecologies. Here, cable companies must grapple with the non-human world.

When building networks into remote environments, cable companies always have to negotiate with local ecologies. In California, negotiation turned to conflict in the late 1990s-early 2000s as environmental organizations such as the California Coastal Commission and the California State Lands Commission put up road blocks to technological development. Out on Midway Island, in the northern Pacific, cable companies actually created the environment: there was no vegetation prior to the cable station. In Cairns, Australia, builders had to find exits out through the Great Barrier Reef.

At remote telegraph stations, cable workers were subject to forces of nature that disrupted their work: hurricanes, snowstorms, and heat waves. In its early days, Guam’s cablemen had difficulties obtaining water and they were not allowed to purchase fresh meat or ice from government stores.  Many station employees fell ill. Cablemen in Newfoundland had to cope with below freezing weather. In Darwin, white ants consumed the insides of walls.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Letter from Percy Geo, Padbury Superintendent; in Barty-King, Girdle Round the Earth, 118.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Moving out into the Pacific from the coast, you hit the barrier reef. If cables are strung across it, they will chafe and soon break. To lay a cable system, companies have to wind it out through the reef's entrances, or in the case of the 1956 cable into Hanauma Bay, blast a hole through the coral. Today Hanauma Bay's reef entrance no longer services cables, but instead guides scuba divers into the bay to explore the ocean's natural wonders.

Many cable stations had to confront extraordinary storms, which would at times disrupt the cablemen's lives, or even the cable station itself. In Rio de Janeiro, one letter from the Superintendent from the station reports: “the terrible storm on the night of the 19th inst. has rendered the building in most parts dangerous and uninhabitable… There were only three bedrooms dry, all the others were inundated; beds and personal effects were all drenched.” Given the station’s limited budget, they had barely enough money for silverware. Where it lacked adequate insulation, the station’s operations were jeopardized, not only through structural damage, but also though the operators’ morale since poor living conditions could affect their accuracy.

The most spectacular and extensive cable disruptions have been caused by earthquakes. Yet the earthquake itself is rarely the direct source of the cable break. More often, these geological shifts generate undersea landslides and seafloor turbulence that sever the network.

Cables are subject to the winds of typhoons, the rising waters of a turbulent ocean, and sudden movements of the earth’s tectonic plates. Landslides and fires threaten to take out cable stations from nearby hills. These are places where natural disasters endanger global communications.
Cables don't always extend smoothly through the world, but come up against conflicts - from both people and nature.

Communications networks have been critical during armed conflicts, providing near real-time information about enemy positions and conditions on the battlefield. Even during peacetime, cables prove important for military operations. They enable remote communications between military bases and installations around the world.

Here, those who control the cable systems meet resistance. In 1900, the Boxer rebellion in China severed lines between Beijing and the coast, cutting the cable at Taku. Once colonial powers suppressed the uprising, the British laid undersea cables between Shanghai and Weihaiwei out at sea, where they could not be severed by opposition.

Cable stations are strategically valuable and have become targets during wartime. In 1914, the Germans attacked cable stations at both Fanning Island and Cocos Island with the aim of cutting major communication routes across the Pacific and Indian Oceans. During World War II, Japanese planes bombed the Sumay cable station in Guam. Severing undersea communications lines isn't a key tactic in war today, but cable stations still have to be located on friendly, accessible territory and secured from potential threats. For this reason, places like Fanning Island are no longer strategic hubs, while islands such Guam are.
Piracy can pose a problem for contemporary cable systems. Cable ships have to beware of pirates, especially in the Indian Ocean, and some cable crews arm themselves to prepare for hostile encounters.
Cables are constructed from raw materials drawn from around the world. Choices about these materials can in turn affect who controls the cable network.

British companies dominated the early telegraph network not only due to their mastery of cable-laying technology, but in part because of their control over the extraction and processing of gutta-percha, a rubber-like gum from Malaysian trees that was used to insulate cable systems.
